975133971033059330.text:
TL;DR on GrayKey as far as my understanding goes:

* Likely on-device device PIN bruteforcing tool.
* To protect yourself: choose strong alphanumeric passphrase or random 9 or 10 digit PIN to protect your phone.

Text snippets from Apple’s iOS guide:

https://www.apple.com/business/docs/iOS_Security_Guide.pdf …

7/7

975131457294405632.text:
I personally like a complex alphanumeric passphrase combined with biometric for day-to-day use. You can force password fallback for iPhone X by holding side button + volume up for a couple seconds.
Others may prefer 9 or 10 digit random PIN. Important that PIN is RANDOM! 6/

975128923305635840.text: So it seems best protection against GrayKey is to choose a strong, alphanumeric passphrase. A random 16-letter passphrase would take around 59 billion millennia to brute force even if only lowercase letters were used. A random 9 digit PIN takes ~2.5 years to brute force. 5/

975126258102173696.text: Published times for GrayKey device seems consistent with the above numbers for raw on-device brute forcing plus some overhead to perhaps reset state to avoid lockouts/wipes. From article we can also see a heuristic strategy checking for repeated 3-digit passcodes like 987987.  4/pic.twitter.com/CgiAZKyVV3

975123013870989314.text: Low-level iPhone hardware security uses a Key Derivation Function (KDF) and an device-specific secret (UID) to enforce that each password entry takes ~80ms. If this is the only defense then a 4 digit pin is broken in less than 13 min and a 6 digit one in less than 22 hours. 3/pic.twitter.com/bin96OiQkv

975120607456178187.text: This seems consistent with GrayKey exploiting a vulnerability that allows them to brute force the user passphrase without the normal lockouts i.e they can avoid the escalating time delays and wipe after 10 failed attempts. 2/pic.twitter.com/bhmPCJ1hBF
